content:
Hyndburn Borough Council runs most of its services in-house with an estimated 137 staff, while neighbouring Burnley and Pendle have outsourced significant service areas to private contractors. How do these models compare on cost, quality, and democratic accountability — and is anyone actually measuring?

Three Councils, Three Models

The three East Lancashire district councils have taken markedly different approaches to service delivery:

Council Model Est. Annual Cost Cost Per Resident Est. Staff Democratic Control
HyndburnMostly in-house~£5-6M (estimated)~£62-74~137High — direct management
BurnleyOutsourced to Liberata£3.4M~£38N/A (contractor)Medium — contract governance
PendleOutsourced to Liberata~£2.4M/year~£26N/A (contractor)Low — largest proportionate spend

Note: Hyndburn's in-house cost is estimated because the council does not publish a single comparable figure for the services that Liberata provides to Burnley and Pendle. This lack of comparable data is itself part of the problem.

What Does Liberata Provide?

Liberata is a private company that provides back-office and customer-facing services to councils. For Burnley and Pendle, the contracted services typically include:

  • Revenues and benefits: Council tax collection, business rates, housing benefit processing
  • Customer services: Contact centre, reception, online enquiries
  • Financial processing: Accounts payable, accounts receivable, payroll
  • ICT services: Technology infrastructure and support

Pendle's Liberata contract is reportedly worth £16.7 million over the contract period — making it the largest proportionate outsourcing commitment relative to council budget of the three councils. This is a significant delegation of core council functions to a private company.

The Case for In-House Delivery

Hyndburn's in-house model has genuine advantages:

  • Direct accountability: Staff report to council managers who report to elected members. There is no contractual barrier between the council and service delivery
  • No profit extraction: Every pound spent on in-house services goes to staff wages and service delivery, not to shareholder returns
  • Flexibility: The council can change processes, priorities, and staffing without renegotiating a contract
  • Staff loyalty and local knowledge: In-house teams build institutional knowledge and community relationships over time
  • No contract transition costs: Outsourcing contracts involve expensive procurement, transition, and mobilisation phases

The Case for Outsourcing

Burnley and Pendle's outsourced model also has defensible advantages:

  • Economies of scale: Liberata serves multiple councils and can spread technology and management costs across a larger base
  • Specialist expertise: A dedicated revenues and benefits company can invest in specialist training and systems
  • Risk transfer: Performance targets and financial penalties can be written into contracts
  • Potential savings: Burnley's £3.4M annual cost may be lower than running equivalent services in-house
  • Technology investment: Large contractors can invest in modern systems that individual small councils cannot afford

The Critical Question: Is Anyone Comparing?

The fundamental problem with Hyndburn's in-house model is not that it is inherently wrong — it is that nobody appears to be benchmarking it. Without rigorous comparison data, it is impossible to know whether Hyndburn's in-house services cost more, less, or about the same as what Liberata charges Burnley and Pendle for equivalent work.

Key comparison metrics that should be published include:

Metric Why It Matters Currently Published?
Cost per council tax account collectedCore efficiency measure for revenuesNo
Housing benefit processing timeSpeed of service to vulnerable claimantsDWP publishes some data
Council tax collection rateRevenue generation effectivenessYes — but not linked to cost
Customer satisfaction scoresService quality from user perspectiveNo
Total cost of in-house vs outsourced modelThe fundamental value-for-money questionNo

The Parkinson Problem: Preference Without Evidence

Cllr Miles Parkinson maintained the in-house model throughout his 12 years as Leader (2011-2023). This may have been the right decision — but it was never demonstrably an evidence-based one.

Under Parkinson's highly centralised leadership, the choice to keep services in-house was effectively a political preference rather than a data-driven strategy. The hallmarks of good decision-making were absent:

  • No published benchmarking: There is no public evidence that Hyndburn systematically compared its in-house costs against outsourced alternatives during Parkinson's tenure
  • No market testing: The council does not appear to have gone to market to test whether private providers could deliver the same services at lower cost
  • No published unit costs: Without unit cost data (cost per transaction, cost per account, cost per call), it is impossible to compare models
  • Centralised decision: The in-house model was maintained by a leader who dominated all major decisions. There was no meaningful scrutiny of whether the model was still delivering the best value after a decade

Keeping services in-house is a defensible choice. Keeping them in-house for 12 years without ever publishing comparative data to prove they offer value for money is not. Under Parkinson, "in-house" became an article of faith rather than an evidence-based policy.

Burnley's Return to In-House: A Cautionary Tale for Everyone

It is worth noting that Burnley Borough Council is reportedly bringing its Liberata services back in-house from 2026. This suggests that the outsourced model has not delivered everything Burnley hoped for either. The grass is not always greener on the other side of a procurement exercise.

This development should inform the debate in several ways:

  • Outsourcing is not a permanent solution — contracts end, and transition costs can be significant both ways
  • The savings from outsourcing may diminish over time as contract extensions and variations accumulate
  • Burnley's experience suggests that in-house delivery may indeed be preferable — but this conclusion should be based on data, not ideology

Questions the Council Should Answer

  1. What is the total annual cost of Hyndburn's in-house revenues, benefits, customer services, and ICT functions?
  2. How does this compare on a per-resident and per-transaction basis to what Burnley and Pendle pay Liberata?
  3. Has the council conducted any formal benchmarking exercise in the last 10 years?
  4. What are the unit costs for key transactions: council tax account management, housing benefit processing, customer service calls?
  5. Has the council sought any external advice on service delivery model options?
  6. What technology investments have been made to support in-house delivery, and how do these compare to what Liberata provides?

The in-house vs outsourced debate should be resolved by evidence, not ideology. Hyndburn residents deserve to know whether their model is delivering better or worse value than the alternatives — and that requires the council to publish the data.

Cost estimates are based on publicly available spending data, FOI responses, and council budget documents. Hyndburn's in-house costs are approximated as directly comparable figures are not published. Readers are encouraged to submit FOI requests for detailed in-house service costs. Burnley's Liberata contract value is based on published transparency data.
